message.content:
We begin by extracting the needed amounts from the three statements.

Step 1. Operating Cash Flow to Net Income Ratio 
• From the Cash Flow statement, the Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities is –18,924,462.44.
• From the Income Statement, the Net Profit is 1,842,166.21.
• Ratio = (Operating Cash Flow) / (Net Profit) = –18,924,462.44 / 1,842,166.21 ≈ –10.27

Step 2. Current Assets Turnover Ratio 
• For turnover ratios it is common to use revenue divided by average current assets.
• From the Income Statement, Main Business Revenue is 20,318,450.67.
• From the Balance Sheet, Total Current Assets are given as 20,000,000.00 initially and 20,314,894.50 at end.
• Average Current Assets = (20,000,000.00 + 20,314,894.50) / 2 ≈ 20,157,447.25.
• Ratio = Revenue / Average Current Assets = 20,318,450.67 / 20,157,447.25 ≈ 1.01

Step 3. Quick Ratio 
• Quick Ratio is defined as (Current Assets – Inventory) / Current Liabilities.
• From the Balance Sheet, Total Current Assets (end) is 20,314,894.50.
• Inventory (end) is 9,100,000.00.
• Thus “Quick Assets” = 20,314,894.50 – 9,100,000.00 = 11,214,894.50.
• Current Liabilities (end): Accounts Payable is 0.00 and Taxes Payable is 1,015,922.54, so Total Current Liabilities = 1,015,922.54.
• Ratio = 11,214,894.50 / 1,015,922.54 ≈ 11.04

Thus, our calculated ratios are as follows.

{
  "solution": {
    "Operating Cash Flow to Net Income Ratio": "-10.27",
    "Current Assets Turnover Ratio": "1.01",
    "Quick Ratio": "11.04"
  }
}
